intro: Arenaria macradenia var. parishiorum, commonly known as the Parish's sandwort, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Africa. It typically forms dense mats of tiny, fleshy, blue-green leaves that are adapted to arid and rocky environments. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers during the spring and summer months, which are clustered in dense inflorescences. It is well-suited to rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in full sun. Its compact growth habit and drought tolerance make it a popular choice for rock gardens and xeriscaping.
